intro: Quercus poilanei, commonly known as the Madagascar oak, is a deciduous tree native to the island of Madagascar. It belongs to the Fagaceae family, which includes oaks, beeches, and chestnuts. The tree is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that turn yellow in the autumn. It produces small, spiky acorns that are an important food source for local wildlife. Quercus poilanei is often found in dry forests and is adapted to the unique climate of its native habitat.
